instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD. When you see ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Got this machine that doesn't boot up but charges the battery. Non liquid spills at all, the board look very good.
I get 20v on both usb C adapter voltmeter and most of the power rails seems to be solid except for the cpu s0 related power rails...
CPU heatsink gets little bit warm but pressing power button does't seems to do anything.
Any suggestions? What to look at next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Sorry for the worts explanatory title ... forgot to edit before post it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
No liquid, but there should be an history.
However, inspect audio board for liquid sign on both sides.

Try DFU revive.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Sorry, didn't get a clear picture from the customer. "Suddenly It just stopped to boot...".
I entered DFU, tried revive, no change, than tried a restore (they have a data backup...) finished with a big padlock symbol on the configurator 2 window which I definately ignore the meaning of (is it locked? in wich way?). Nothing changed. Still no booting up. I inspected the audio board wich appears to be fine with no traces of liquid spill and also no shorts on the main caps. The bottom side still well coated and didn't feel to screew it up with furthure investigations at this time. When battery disconnected I get 20V/ 0,04 amps reading. When battery is connected I get (on both USB-C ports) 20V 1,74A reading from the voltage meter.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
If stays at 40mA, the board doesn't turn on.
Do you get any voltage at L7670?
If not, check pin 4/<CHIP>U7650</CHIP> level.
Check for short any big coils and all secondary supplies.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
yes solid 5v on L7670
and 3.3 V on L7690. Get also 12V on L7030 with no battery and  when battery connected decreasing 4,5V during charge (charging normally I assume...)
The customer said she previously nstalled Big Sur, may be the issue came after a furture update of the os? She also brig it to an apple authorized service provider as soon as it happened and they offered her motherboard replcement for 400€...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: by the way is it normal that in configurator 2 the macbook air is recognized as an Apple Controller? Just performed a new restore ended up with another padlock symbol ...???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: No other hints? Should I reallly let the customer bring this machine to Apple for a mobo swap?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PCH_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Once I press PWRBTN <SIGNAL>PCH_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  goes low. That means PHC knows at least that have been triggered to power on. What next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> at same time.
Be sure <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> is high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> solid 3.3
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> two seconds after enabling power goes to 3.3 stable no pulse

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> solid 3.3"
Then you should have S3 voltages present.
Check <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> too; it controls S0 voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> allready measured... 3.3v stable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Something is preventing the board to go to s0. Ram voltage also ok

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Check voltage on all coils; which one not present?

RAM voltage is in S3 state.
If <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> is high, you must have some S0 voltages.
Don't forget to check page 67.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Sure, I'll let you know when I'll get back to work tomorrow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Found 0,9v on L8102
No voltages on L7410, L7430, L7210, L7230
cpu get warm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: I wonder if I get <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R</SIGNAL> I should also have <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>, etc... Am I right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Any power supply which sends power good signal to <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, should be then present.
Now <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is used to generate that signal, but it considers all mentioned voltages.
We don't have direct connection between power good signals, like in old platforms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> also 1,8V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
How do I find out what is the missing signal or bad components that prevents the machin to power up ? I guess if <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> could be the cause.

What other signals should I check for in order to narrow down the search to the required ones for booting at least?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Looks like missing CPU core power.
Could be CPU itself the culprit; or PCH, which is embedded in the same package.

Did you test with charger and battery, both connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: No, I didn't connect the battery during tests. I'll do it but I need to know if the problem could arise in CPU area or somewhere else in the motherboard.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Then do all tests possible, like the above mentioned.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Sure I'll do it but need your suggeasions about what to test next. I arrived at the point that s0 state should already be reached and I wonder why still not powering up. What should I measure to get a clear picture of what is working and what is not? Cpu/pch? How do I know for sure?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD_R</SIGNAL> is enable signal for CPU core power.
Now PCH/CPU and BIOS/T2 control the specific power supply; enable signal is not sufficient.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Ok how do I know if the problem is with the BIOS/T2 or elsewhere? I tried restoring the T2 as I told you before resulting in just a padlock symbol and nothing else at the end of the process. I tought there could be something more straightforward to narrow down the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
This is not an exact science.
We don't have the tools used by manufacturer.
Bad CPU can be a reason for DFU not completed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: I agree but I tought you could have helped me at least in order to get to a diagnose without these tools, I'm not talking about solving the issue right now but at least know what sould be the fault responsable of the issue. If I should blame cpu/pch or BIOS/T2 chip. I do not know if the DFU was completed or not. I haven't found anywere an explanation of the symbol I get after the DFU... I can't say it didn't succeded because I have no experience on this new Apple tool that's why I'm asking the forum for help. I can't belive the only known problem with these machine could be just with the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>... It seems like when the infamous T2 chip gets involved engineers rise their hends up and stop thinking to other possible solutions ;-)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Exact resistance to ground on CPU VCore?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Resistance to ground measured on L7410, L7430, L7210, L7230 is respectively 14, 14, 20,5, 20,5

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
[QUOTE="piernov, post: 75215, member: 1057"]
Exact resistance to ground on CPU VCore?
[/QUOTE]

No other hints? Should I give up on this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
[QUOTE="piernov, post: 75215, member: 1057"]
Exact resistance to ground on CPU VCore?
[/QUOTE]

Did you get any usefull hint from the resistance measures I provided you with?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
I don't have other board to compare.
But I don't see strange values.

Could be CPU, or T2 problem.
Each has lot of internal blocks and is sufficient one not working good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Anybody capable to revive a machine like this in rossmangroup? :eek: Can't belive nobody went so deep in T2 problems solving yet. Hope someone can give me other suggestions in order to salvage this unhappy macbook.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
If you like to waste more time on it, get a logic analyzer and monitor SPI bus and CPU SVID bus (<RESISTOR>R7102</RESISTOR>/04).
CPU works very hot on these machines, without heat pipe; so is the first suspect.
